subject: Re: [junit] question about Assert.assertEquals
msgSnippet: ... Okay, java.util HashSets and TreeSets. According to the contract for the Equals method on the Set Interface, a Set is equal to another set if they are the
messageBody:
JB Wrote:
> Consider the template code:
>
> public boolean equals(Object other) {
> if (other != null && getClass() == other.getClass()) {
> MyClass that = (MyClass) other;
> // compare fields or whatever you like
> }
> else {
> return false;
> }
> }
>
> I claim that this implementation of equals fully supports the
> contract of Object#equals, including the subclass/superclass case. If
> you think that is false, then please show us a test consistent with
> the contract of Object#equals that this implementation does not pass.

Okay, java.util HashSets and TreeSets.

According to the contract for the Equals method on the Set Interface, a
Set is equal to another set if they are the same size, and both contain
the same objects.

Your implementation would return false in this case if one set were a
TreeSet and the other were a HashSet, as the class objects aren't
equal.

We could say that, in Bloch's original example with points, the real
problem is that the ColoredPoint is changing the contract of the equals
method. And, in fact, this is probably what he means by the "add an
aspect" portion of his statement "There is simply no way to extend an
instantiable class and add an aspect while preserving the equals
contract."

-Kevin
